segments.text: in any particular direction, I mean, not petroleum or not.
I mean, it's an open ballgame.
Well, no, but that's just one.
We've got about seven centers out there.

And one of the most important centers that we started, Joe and I started back in 1973, was the Center for Growth Studies, which relates to what's happening to all of us from the standpoint of pressure on the population, environmental things.
That's everything you've been talking about.
Right.
And so therefore, I think it fits.
And Joe put it right that we've got to change the name.
came up the other day.

I don't like to change the name, because we looked at the name, and we finally arrived, and we had Alternative to the Growth, and we had Alternative to the Growth Second Session, and we had, then we hit on the name, the Nature of Sustainable Societies.
That's what we're trying to seek, the Nature of Sustainable Societies.
What is it?
You can't make 5 billion people work.
How are you going to make 10 billion people work?
How's it going to work?
How do we get policies to make it work?
I'm just telling you.
Yeah, I know.
Very serious.
So, but that does, see, the Center for Growth Studies doesn't say that.
It ought to be the Center for Sustainable Society Studies.
I don't know.
You see what I'm talking about?
God, I hate to change that one more time.
I hate to change it.
It started out as a women's conference.
I know.
But think about it.
Am I right?
George Brock brought that up the other day.
I would agree.
We've never had a really good name.
No.
Well, think about it.
You and I have worked on things since 1973.
But see, we've got seven centers out there.
We've got the Accelerator Center, which Peter McIntyre was involved in.
We've got the supercomputer.
We've got...
laser center.
We've got seven centers there, so it does.
And we've got one on energy, geotechnology, that's doing real good work.
And we're trying to get a, what we call a clearinghouse of research that the major company would participate with us and the university and DOE.
That's important for this reason.
Houston did all the, you know, we cover the world with it.
It's all developed in this part of the country.
Our offshore drilling, our seismic work, everything was developed in this part of the country here, Dallas, Fort Worth, Houston.
A little bit to Oklahoma.
I guess there really is no comparable.
There's nothing comparable.
We're going to lose now.
This nation will lose now another 25 years if we don't really get reignited again.
And we really, we're not.
So we're working on that.
That'll be one of the geotechnology functions to try to well the private sector to the university to the government sector.
And with the talent you have in this region,
to stay ahead of research in the world, exploration production research, and, of course, petrochemicals, too.
I'm not worried about petrochemicals, but it couldn't go out.
But the universe is so jealous.
They want to do everything right there in a little thing, and that's fine.
It's very difficult to work with them.
I'm going to tell you, you know about it better than I do.
But we're making progress.
It's very tough and pitiful sometimes.
You're very patient.
You have to have perseverance to work with the universities.
But anyway, that gives you the overall thing, but what we'll do, because we can talk some more about a piece of this thing.
And what do you see as growth projections are very strong out in the Woodlands area right now, for example?
I think so.

And what is this going to do to your... What interests me is to really build the technology center really to the critical mass, I think, that this region deserves, including improving the status of the universities.
I could foresee...
joint appointments with the private sector that works with us and the universities to get the top talent, certainly in petroleum engineering and geology, which we have some, but not the top.
Are you getting cooperation in this?
Very difficult because most people think they've got enough people to do what I'm talking about doing.
Sure.
I would say this in geophysics, you mentioned it several times, I think we've got some good people in the four universities, but not what I think we ought to have.
And I think the private sector would help support it.
You see, the private sector don't want us in it because they stay ahead of us that way.
But in geophysics, I think that we can work on that.
The private sector really doesn't know.
The major companies, the players like we have, we don't have research in exploration production.
He's comparing the majors with the independents.
You see, the private sector majors don't want independents doing research.
They stay ahead of us three years and they don't want us to catch up.
Well, I want to catch up.
So we're working with the Guest Research Institute now.
They just gave us a grant down there.
And universities want all that research in their house.
In their house, yeah.
So you're hearing a very difficult...
Except that they can't get the private sector to relate to them as well as they should.
Right here is where the action is.

See, if we had a research clearinghouse at the private sector that was driven by the private sector and the university talent was brought into it, but the research is driven by the private sector, they're not going to give
Right now, you might start at $15 to $20 million in that type of program.
But I'd say in five years, you could build it with energy the way the problem's going to be.
You could build up to a $500 million program.
It would be enormously important for the university to participate with us.
And the private sector ought to participate.
Because then, right now, I'll give you a good example that'll blow your mind.
In clean coal research out of the Department of Energy, there's now $750 million a year going.
And non-defense nuclear, $2 billion a year.
in oil and gas research at $34 million a year.
Now why?
Is that right?
That's all.
Isn't that shocking?
That is shocking.
I finally got him to admit.
I said, you know why?
Because your major companies stop at all times.
You're not going to stop the other two.
Once you wake up and get a share and you do the research, they put half the money in.
So I'm making some progress.
That's what I'll be doing.
Because if you don't make a major impact in 15, 20 years, if you don't get a half billion dollar project in five years, you're not going to do any good.
But then in the university, you could have joint tenure.
You could have them involved.
You could have the private sector involved.
But they don't trust the university or DOE to do a half a billion dollar research project.
No major companies.
So they'll never get it.
Now, that doesn't stop them from doing the most basic work that they should do.
But when you're trying to get the stuff that goes to the private sector, you better have the private sector involved.
Now, that's what I'm trying to convince them, and it ought to be in Houston.
Do you think there's been much real transfusion, let's say, of new technology into the petroleum industry in the last decade or so?
Yeah, I think there's some.
I think there's some.
But I think we find by these venture capital that we have put together, the most difficult thing is to get anything out of the universities that makes sense.
Now, I think that if we could help them devise a program, we could help them make sense.
Well, are you telling me in a way that the American petroleum industry is in very much the same situation
They, let's say, as the American iron and steel industry was 50 years ago.
Yeah, I can say the major presence were Neanderthals.
Yeah, and that's what happened to iron and steel.
It's obvious from their PR relation.
They should have had Joe on their staff.
We got a good PR thanks to Joe and his effort the last 20 years.
They got a horrible PR.
Why?
When they didn't have enough perception that when the gas oil price went up to stop many gas prices as much as they could from going up and let people know what they're trying to do, they're stupid.
Now we're going to have three hearings on gouging and none on what we're going to do about sovereign energy.
Let me just tell you.
So I would say that why I'm so adamant on that research, and I think they're wrong,
It's a billion-dollar research on exploration and production research.
That's, of course, the exploration end.
So I put a simple pencil to it.
The gross revenues they get out of production, exploration production, is $150 billion.
Now, to spend only a billion, there's something wrong with them.
You see what I'm talking about?
Yep.
They ought to be spending $4 or $5 billion a year, at least.

him spend seven percent of the gross income etc they've been in the dark ages too long now they think they got all the bases covered yeah that does sound like iron and steel yeah really i hadn't even thought about that i've never made that connection yet they've been so smart for the last 30 40 years mainly because they're chased by a 10 000 independence they've covered the world then they won't let us produce it but i think that they're losing out in this country yeah and i think that we've got to fire them up it ought to be in houston so that's where

used to advance research and then you're working our problem is universities oh no i want it over here and fisher said he wants it in austin and ufa says i want over here you know sure so i've got to kind of be uh working with them make them all say we're going to all benefit by it let's see what we can do well i know it's silly to ask you if you're optimistic because obviously you are but what do you see as the next great hurdle or breakthrough or obstacle that you've got to
surmount in terms of developing that complex.
You mean in the woodlands?
In the woodlands.
I think it's important that the commercial and the high tech thing begins to become as effective and really as aggressive as we're doing in the residential.
Very good.
Yes.
But right now, because of Houston's problems, and I'd say that the west side beat us with a draw on the energy corridor.
We got some out there, but not as much as the west side.
But we got this airport.
And there's no way to expand at any other airport.
So we're going to be riding a driver.
We've got a toll road, as you know.
Yeah, I use it every week almost.
And it didn't end up with the Woodlands by accident.
A lot of work went by.
How about rail, the monorail or whatever?
Working on rail is a possibility.
We got one like Kit Lanier.
I've done it before.
They spent $65 million.
He was the head of the MTA here for a while.
I kid him.
I said, you know, you spent $65 million.
I've only spent six rounds down.
I've got a train going to Dallas right now.
Why do I have them?
You've got something going.
However, we think that rail could be a possibility to the women and further out.

So I think that, you know, those are the things that get along because you need to get people into the big city and have all the downtown be a main downtown and have all the cultural centers or most of it here, et cetera, et cetera, legal professional.
We have to be part of the whole.
And we should develop.
They should never put the summit out there where they did.
The summit should be in here.
This area should be really the Brown Center.
You still have to have that hub here.
But then you have to have these employment areas and commercial areas and nodes around.
And then where you all hold one of the hope.
Because if you're a separate community out there, it won't work.
And when you economically integrate that community, you still anticipate that a substantial core of that group actually will come downtown.
In other words, this is the mixing bowl.
Well, I think in some functions they should come downtown, if you have good transit.
How do you compare, incidentally, the Dallas economic region to Houston?
Dallas has more defense, and they're aggressive.
They've got a good bunch of people working in Dallas, Perot and all that bunch.
But see, Dallas made a mistake not taking advantage of the exterritorial jurisdictions.
They got a lot of independent subdivisions around Dallas.
Terribly independent, yeah.
They were in trouble.
They were in trouble because of Plano, et cetera, et cetera, et cetera.
So Dallas really made a mistake not doing what we're trying to do.
I had to fight Kathy Whitmire, not fight her, but first month in office.
I told her, I need that rail from the north to get to the new airport.
How are you going to get to the airport in five years, Kathy?
You're building a billion-hour airport and you can't get there.
That's right.
She wouldn't do it.
She wouldn't do it the whole world.
I said, the second thing is you came on for the city and you came on the
premise that she would have Clear Lake City DNX from Houston.
She's so thankful that she didn't get it done.
I argued with her, and she was still going to try to do it, and we got it beat.
Because if Clear Lake City and NASA had been DNXed from Houston, it would have been a divorce.
That's an example I'm using for Kathy.
She won't admit it now, but she was dead against it.
She wanted DNXed.
That was what she wrote right on the platform.
I said, those are two things you're really wrong, Captain.
She won't listen.
She listens now.
She's really brightened.
She made a hell of a plea for Japan's service today, talking about it at the Houston Partnership meeting.
She's really gotten where she worked for the private sector, but she was so suspicious of them at the beginning that she thought it was just all self-interest.
But she's the bright gal.
She's done a good job.
What's happening in Texas?
I think the war is going to make Texas much better.
I think the price is not going to go back to $10 or $12 again for long ever, I don't think.
For the next 10 years, I think that it's bad for the nation, and I think that our economy should be better, particularly Houston.
And we'll just see when gas prices go low.
This one gas price is going.
That's the thing it was, but now gas prices are low.
But the bubble on coal-seamed gas bothers me a little bit.
I'm not so sure.
Say that again.
Coal-seamed gas is coming in strong.
And it's a concern as to whether the bubble's going to be gone this winter for the normal winter or not.
I think it will be.
But the price of gas will go up anyway because oil is going to go up.
I was serious when I first walked in.
Is there a relationship?
For example, when you started the Woodlands, the real housing development, we had the OPEC embargo and so forth.
And you had a tough time selling, probably.
Very tough time.
Do you see that happening again?
The interest rates went up to 14%, 15%.
And everything, inflation got out of control.
It really hurt us.
That was the key to it.
That hurt us.
The inflation got out of control.
It may not get out of control, but it might get out of control.
So if prices can go up and interest rates stay down, you're fixed.
It came in 35% over budget, and that hurt us.
Yeah.
And that's because inflation just gnawed us to pieces.
Also, I think that the fact that we're going so fast, we probably should have figured out how to make it more palatable.
Mm-hmm.
But, Henry, you're going to be allowed to come back.
All right.
I don't know what your schedule is, but I don't know when it's here.
Yeah, well, we'll have more time to talk about it in the future.
Okay, good.
We'll stop right here.
We'll stop right here and we'll pick it up.
Come back.
I really appreciate it.
Thank you.
That's been a good, nice, good, constructive overview.
Thank you.
Joe learned a lot today.
